context: Coincidentally, I can think of about 2.5 billion things that would be more important and relevant to study at this time.

context:
"......the Berkeley team said the total population could be as little as 140 
million or as much as 42 billion with 2.4 billion as the middle value". So basically they don't know how many there were.

replies.context: Fox News wanted an eye catching headline for the article so they went with the big number.

context: In the final analysis, although it's interesting to put a number to the T-Rex population estimate, it's still just a swag.  No way to prove it, but a neat argument.

replies.context: It is just a thought experiment to talk about over a beer.

context: now think about how many mid-sized and small dinosaurian predators there will - which would have outnumbered the tyrannosaurs at the top of the food chain by many times ...

I am beginning to think that Paleontologists and their ilk MAY be the least creatively inclined group on the planet.  They need to use some of their funds to hire actual and believable creative writers, who can paint a picture that is not so obviously stilted and silly....or a novelty for the science of today...maybe tell the truth and present that they really have no idea and present their actual creative ideas as JUST that....not fact etc....its getting old and not good for the people's perception of science in general.  They are fast gaining on the climate crowd among others.

I am still amazed by the people who wrongly believe the non-avian dinosaurs all died out 4000 years ago. Their opinions should be considered null and void on any topic because they have already forfeited common sense and critical thinking. Those poor uneducated rubes...
